noun.description: Scottish and English regional. A gentle or weak kick or push.

verb.description: To kick (something); to paw (the ground) with a foot; to stamp (one's foot). Now English regional (northern).
To poke (a fire, etc.) with a stick, poker, etc. Now Scottish and English regional (northern).

origin: Late Middle English (in an earlier sense). From pote. For early use compare plough-pote<br>Old English (in an earlier sense). Probably cognate with Middle Dutch pōten to stick in the ground, to secure, to graft (Dutch poten to plant), Middle Low German pōten, pāten, patten to plant, to graft, Icelandic pota to poke, thrust, Norwegian (Nynorsk) pota to poke, Swedish regional påta to poke, to poke about, Danish pode to graft, to plant; further etymology uncertain: apparently related to put.
